Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When I was a teen, I had terrible periods. I had crippling cramps, I leaked blood onto my clothes
and onto my bed sheets, and I had period diarrhea. And I had to miss school
one to two days a month, and I remember sitting on the couch
with my heating pads, thinking, "What's up with this?" When I ate food, I didn't leak saliva
from my salivary glands. When I went for a walk, I didn't leak fluid from my knees, 
"joint fluid." Why was menstruation so different? I wanted answers to these questions but there was no one for me to ask. My mother knew nothing about menstruation except that it was dirty and shameful
and I shouldn't talk about it. I asked girlfriends and everybody spoke in euphemisms. And finally, when I got the courage
to go to the doctor and talk about my heavy periods, I was told to eat liver. (Laughter) And when I went to the drug store
to buy my menstrual products, my 48-pack of super maxi pads, back in the day when they were the size
of a tissue box, each pad -- (Laughter) You know what I'm talking about. You have no idea how far
absorbent technology has come. (Laughter) I used to have to buy
my menstrual products in the feminine hygiene aisle. And I remember standing there, thinking, "Well, why don't I buy toilet paper
in the anal hygiene aisle?" (Laughter) Like, what's up with that? Why can't we talk about periods? And it's not about the blood,
as Freud would have you say, because if it were, there would be an ear, nose
and throat surgeon up here right now, talking about the taboos
of nose bleeds, right? And it's not even about periods, because otherwise, when we got rid
of our toxic, shameful periods when we became menopausal, we'd be elevated
to a higher social status. (Laughter) (Applause) It's just a patriarchal society is
invested in oppressing women, and at different points in our lives,
different things are used. And menstruation is used during what we in medicine call
the reproductive years. It's been around since
pretty much the beginning of time, many cultures thought
that women could spoil crops or milk, or wilt flowers. And then when religion came along, purity myths only made that worse. And medicine wasn't any help. In the 1920s and '30s there was the idea that women elaborated
something called a menotoxin. We could wilt flowers just by walking by. (Laughter) And that's what happens
when there's no diversity, right. Because there was no woman
to put her hand up and go, "Well, actually, that doesn't happen." And when you can't talk
about what's happening to your body, how do you break these myths? Because you don't even need to be a doctor to say that periods aren't toxic. If they were, why would an embryo
implant in a toxic swill? And if we all had this secret menotoxin, we could be laying waste
to crops and spoiling milk. (Laughter) Why would we have not used
our X-Women powers to get the vote sooner? (Laughter) (Applause) Even now, when I tweet about period diarrhea, as one does, (Laughter) I mention that it affects
28 percent of women. And every single time,
someone approaches me and says, "I thought I was the only one." That's how effective
that culture of shame is, that women can't even share
their experiences. So I began to think, "Well, what if everybody knew
about periods like a gynecologist? Wouldn't that be great?" Then you would all know what I know, you'd know that menstruation is a pretty unique
phenomenon among mammals. Most mammals have estrus. Humans, some primates, some bats, the elephant shrew
and the spiny mouse menstruate. And with menstruation what happens is
the brain triggers the ovary to start producing an egg. Estrogen is released and it starts to build up
the lining of the uterus, cell upon cell, like bricks. And what happens if you build
a brick wall too high without mortar? Well, it's unstable. So what happens when you ovulate? You release a hormone called progesterone, which is progestational,
it gets the uterus ready. It acts like a mortar
and it holds those bricks together. It also causes some changes to make the lining more hospitable
for implantation. If there's no pregnancy, (Whoosh) lining comes out, there's bleeding from the blood vessels
and that's the period. And I always find this point
really interesting. Because with estrus, the final signaling to get
the lining of the uterus ready actually comes from the embryo. But with menstruation, that choice comes from the ovary. It's as if choice is coded in
to our reproductive tracts. (Cheering and applause) OK, so now we know why the blood is there. And it's a pretty significant amount. It's 30 to 90 milliliters of blood, which is one to three ounces, and it can be more, and I know it seems like it's more
a lot of the times. I know. So why do we have so much blood? And why doesn't it just stay there
till the next cycle, right? Like, you didn't get pregnant,
so why can't it hang around? Well imagine if each month it got thicker
and thicker and thicker, right, like, imagine what tsunami
period that would be. (Laughter) We can't reabsorb it,
because it's too much. And it's too much because we need
a thick uterine lining for a very specific reason. Pregnancy exerts a significant
biological toll on our bodies. There is maternal mortality, there is the toll of breastfeeding and there is the toll of raising a child
until it is independent. And evolution -- (Laughter) That goes on longer
for some of us than others. (Laughter) But evolution knows
about risk-benefit ratio. And so evolution wants to maximize
the chance of a beneficial outcome. And how do you maximize the chance
of a beneficial outcome? You try to get the highest
quality embryos. And how do you get
the highest quality embryos? You make them work for it. You give them an obstacle course. So over the millennia
that we have evolved, it's been a little bit
like an arms race in the uterus, the lining getting thicker
and thicker and thicker, and the embryo getting more invasive until we reach this détente with the lining
of the uterus that we have. So we have this thick uterine lining and now it's got to come out, and how do you stop bleeding? Well, you stop a nose bleed
by pinching it, if you cut your leg,
you put pressure on it. We stop bleeding with pressure. When we menstruate, the lining of the uterus
releases substances that are made into chemicals
called prostaglandins and other inflammatory mediators. And they make the uterus cramp down, they make it squeeze
on those blood vessels to stop the bleeding. They might also change
blood flow to the uterus and also cause inflammation
and that makes pain worse. And so you say, "OK,
how much pressure is generated?" And from studies
where some incredible women have volunteered
to have pressure catheters put in their uterus that they wear
their whole menstrual cycle -- God bless them, because
we wouldn't have this knowledge without, and it's very important knowledge, because the pressure
that's generated in the uterus during menstruation is 120 millimeters of mercury. "Well what's that," you say. Well, it's the amount of pressure
that's generated during the second stage of labor
when you're pushing. (Audience gasps) Right. Which, for those of you
who haven't had an unmedicated delivery, that's what it's like
when the blood pressure cuff is not quite as tight as it was
at the beginning, but it's still pretty tight, and you wish it would stop. So that kind of makes it different, right? If you start thinking
about the pain of menstruation, we wouldn't say
if someone needed to miss school because they were in the second stage
of labor and pushing, we wouldn't call them weak. We'd be like, "Oh my God,
you made it that far," right? (Laughter) And we wouldn't deny pain control to women who have
typical pain of labor, right? So it's important for us to call this pain
"typical" instead of "normal," because when we say it's normal,
it's easier to dismiss. As opposed to saying it's typical,
and we should address it. And we do have some ways
to address menstrual pain. One way is with something
called a TENS unit, which you can wear under your clothes and it sends an electrical impulse
to the nerves and muscles and no one really knows how it works, but we think it might be
the gate theory of pain, which is counterirritation. It's the same reason why,
if you hurt yourself, you rub it. Vibration travels faster
to your brain than pain does. We also have medications called nonsteroidal
anti-inflammatory medications. And what they do is they block
the release of prostaglandins. They can reduce menstrual pain
for 80 percent of women. They also reduce the volume of blood
by 30 to 40 percent and they can help with period diarrhea. And we also have hormonal contraception, which gives us a thinner
lining of the uterus, so there's less prostaglandins produced and with less blood,
there's less need for cramping. Now, if those treatments fail you -- and it's important to use
that word choice, because we never fail the treatment, the treatment fails us. If that treatment fails you, you could be amongst the people who have a resistance
to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories. We don't quite understand, but there are some complex mechanisms why those medications
just don't work for some women. It's also possible that you could have another reason for painful periods. You could have a condition
called endometriosis, where the lining of the uterus
is growing in the pelvic cavity, causing inflammation
and scar tissue and adhesions. And there may be other mechanisms
we don't quite understand yet, because it's a possibility
that pain thresholds could be different due to very complex biological mechanisms. But we're only going to find that out
by talking about it. It shouldn't be an act of feminism to know how your body works. It shouldn't -- (Applause) It shouldn't be an act of feminism to ask for help when you're suffering. The era of menstrual taboos is over. (Cheers and applause) The only curse here is the ability to convince
half the population that the very biological machinery
that perpetuates the species, that gives everything that we have, is somehow dirty or toxic. And I'm not going to stand for it. (Applause) And the way we break that curse? It's knowledge. Thank you. (Cheers and applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Most mammals have ______:
Options: A. Menstruation, B. Estrus, C. Pregnancy, D. Ovaries
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the speaker's experience with menstruation like as a teenager? Options: A. She had light and manageable periods., B. She had typical periods with some cramping., C. She had terrible periods with crippling cramps, heavy bleeding, and period diarrhea., D. She did not experience menstruation until her early twenties. Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why did the speaker's doctor recommend she eat liver? Options: A. To help with menstrual cramps., B. To reduce heavy bleeding., C. To address period diarrhea., D. To treat her heavy periods, although the reason is not specified. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the speaker's argument about the stigma surrounding menstruation? Options: A. It's because of the blood and mess involved., B. It's because of patriarchal society's investment in oppressing women., C. It's because of the pain and discomfort associated with menstruation., D. It's because of the inconvenience it causes. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the purpose of the hormone progesterone in the menstrual cycle? Options: A. To trigger ovulation., B. To thicken the uterine lining., C. To prepare the uterus for implantation and hold the uterine lining together., D. To reduce menstrual cramps. Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why can't the uterine lining just stay in the uterus until the next cycle? Options: A. Because it's too thin., B. Because it's too thick and can't be reabsorbed., C. Because it's not needed anymore., D. Because it's toxic. Correct Option: None
Question 6: According to the speaker, why do humans have a thick uterine lining? Options: A. To support the growth of the embryo., B. To prepare the uterus for implantation., C. To maximize the chance of a beneficial outcome by making embryos work for it., D. To reduce menstrual cramps. Correct Option: None
Question 7: How does the uterus stop bleeding during menstruation? Options: A. By releasing hormones to reduce blood flow., B. By cramping down on the blood vessels to stop the bleeding., C. By reabsorbing the blood., D. By releasing more blood to flush out the uterus. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the pressure generated in the uterus during menstruation comparable to? Options: A. The pressure of a blood pressure cuff., B. The pressure during the first stage of labor., C. The pressure during the second stage of labor when pushing., D. The pressure of a headache. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is one way to address menstrual pain, according to the speaker? Options: A. Using a heating pad., B. Taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications., C. Practicing yoga., D. Using a TENS unit. Correct Option: None
Question 10: According to the speaker, why is it essential to talk about menstruation and break the menstrual taboos? Options: A. To promote feminism., B. To reduce menstrual cramps., C. To increase knowledge and understanding of the female body., D. To encourage the use of hormonal contraception. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not explicitly present in the list. However, based on the content and intent of the ground truth MCQ, I can suggest a related generated MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the reproductive phenomenon most mammals have (estrus). A related generated MCQ is Question 4, which asks about the purpose of the hormone progesterone in the menstrual cycle. Although it's not a direct match, it's related to the menstrual cycle and reproductive phenomena.

However, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the concept of estrus or menstrual cycles in mammals, I would suggest Question 6. It asks about the reason humans have a thick uterine lining, which is related to the menstrual cycle and reproductive phenomena in humans.

Please note that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. If I had to choose an index, I would suggest Question 6 (index 6) as a related generated MCQ, but with the understanding that it's not a direct match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When I was a teen, I had terrible periods. I had crippling cramps, I leaked blood onto my clothes
and onto my bed sheets, and I had period diarrhea. And I had to miss school
one to two days a month, and I remember sitting on the couch
with my heating pads, thinking, "What's up with this?" When I ate food, I didn't leak saliva
from my salivary glands. When I went for a walk, I didn't leak fluid from my knees, 
"joint fluid." Why was menstruation so different? I wanted answers to these questions but there was no one for me to ask. My mother knew nothing about menstruation except that it was dirty and shameful
and I shouldn't talk about it. I asked girlfriends and everybody spoke in euphemisms. And finally, when I got the courage
to go to the doctor and talk about my heavy periods, I was told to eat liver. (Laughter) And when I went to the drug store
to buy my menstrual products, my 48-pack of super maxi pads, back in the day when they were the size
of a tissue box, each pad -- (Laughter) You know what I'm talking about. You have no idea how far
absorbent technology has come. (Laughter) I used to have to buy
my menstrual products in the feminine hygiene aisle. And I remember standing there, thinking, "Well, why don't I buy toilet paper
in the anal hygiene aisle?" (Laughter) Like, what's up with that? Why can't we talk about periods? And it's not about the blood,

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When you ovulate, you release a hormone called ______:
Options: A. Cortisol, B. Estrogen, C. Testosterone, D. Progesterone
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When I was a teen, I had terrible periods. I had crippling cramps, I leaked blood onto my clothes
and onto my bed sheets, and I had period diarrhea. And I had to miss school
one to two days a month, and I remember sitting on the couch
with my heating pads, thinking, "What's up with this?" When I ate food, I didn't leak saliva
from my salivary glands. When I went for a walk, I didn't leak fluid from my knees, 
"joint fluid." Why was menstruation so different? I wanted answers to these questions but there was no one for me to ask. My mother knew nothing about menstruation except that it was dirty and shameful
and I shouldn't talk about it. I asked girlfriends and everybody spoke in euphemisms. And finally, when I got the courage
to go to the doctor and talk about my heavy periods, I was told to eat liver. (Laughter) And when I went to the drug store
to buy my menstrual products, my 48-pack of super maxi pads, back in the day when they were the size
of a tissue box, each pad -- (Laughter) You know what I'm talking about. You have no idea how far

till the next cycle, right? Like, you didn't get pregnant,
so why can't it hang around? Well imagine if each month it got thicker
and thicker and thicker, right, like, imagine what tsunami
period that would be. (Laughter) We can't reabsorb it,
because it's too much. And it's too much because we need
a thick uterine lining for a very specific reason. Pregnancy exerts a significant
biological toll on our bodies. There is maternal mortality, there is the toll of breastfeeding and there is the toll of raising a child
until it is independent. And evolution -- (Laughter) That goes on longer
for some of us than others. (Laughter) But evolution knows
about risk-benefit ratio. And so evolution wants to maximize
the chance of a beneficial outcome. And how do you maximize the chance
of a beneficial outcome? You try to get the highest
quality embryos. And how do you get
the highest quality embryos? You make them work for it. You give them an obstacle course. So over the millennia
that we have evolved, it's been a little bit
like an arms race in the uterus, the lining getting thicker
and thicker and thicker, and the embryo getting more invasive until we reach this détente with the lining
of the uterus that we have. So we have this thick uterine lining and now it's got to come out, and how do you stop bleeding? Well, you stop a nose bleed
by pinching it, if you cut your leg,
you put pressure on it. We stop bleeding with pressure. When we menstruate, the lining of the uterus
releases substances that are made into chemicals
called prostaglandins and other inflammatory mediators. And they make the uterus cramp down, they make it squeeze
on those blood vessels to stop the bleeding. They might also change
blood flow to the uterus and also cause inflammation
and that makes pain worse. And so you say, "OK,
how much pressure is generated?" And from studies
where some incredible women have volunteered
to have pressure catheters put in their uterus that they wear
their whole menstrual cycle -- God bless them, because
we wouldn't have this knowledge without, and it's very important knowledge, because the pressure
that's generated in the uterus during menstruation is 120 millimeters of mercury. "Well what's that," you say. Well, it's the amount of pressure
that's generated during the second stage of labor
when you're pushing. (Audience gasps) Right. Which, for those of you
who haven't had an unmedicated delivery, that's what it's like
when the blood pressure cuff is not quite as tight as it was
at the beginning, but it's still pretty tight, and you wish it would stop. So that kind of makes it different, right? If you start thinking
about the pain of menstruation, we wouldn't say
if someone needed to miss school because they were in the second stage
of labor and pushing, we wouldn't call them weak. We'd be like, "Oh my God,
you made it that far," right? (Laughter) And we wouldn't deny pain control to women who have
typical pain of labor, right? So it's important for us to call this pain
"typical" instead of "normal," because when we say it's normal,
it's easier to dismiss. As opposed to saying it's typical,
and we should address it. And we do have some ways
to address menstrual pain. One way is with something
called a TENS unit, which you can wear under your clothes and it sends an electrical impulse
to the nerves and muscles and no one really knows how it works, but we think it might be
the gate theory of pain, which is counterirritation. It's the same reason why,
if you hurt yourself, you rub it. Vibration travels faster
to your brain than pain does. We also have medications called nonsteroidal
anti-inflammatory medications. And what they do is they block
the release of prostaglandins. They can reduce menstrual pain
for 80 percent of women. They also reduce the volume of blood
by 30 to 40 percent and they can help with period diarrhea. And we also have hormonal contraception, which gives us a thinner
lining of the uterus, so there's less prostaglandins produced and with less blood,
there's less need for cramping. Now, if those treatments fail you -- and it's important to use
that word choice, because we never fail the treatment, the treatment fails us. If that treatment fails you, you could be amongst the people who have a resistance
to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories. We don't quite understand, but there are some complex mechanisms why those medications
just don't work for some women. It's also possible that you could have another reason for painful periods. You could have a condition
called endometriosis, where the lining of the uterus
is growing in the pelvic cavity, causing inflammation
and scar tissue and adhesions. And there may be other mechanisms
we don't quite understand yet, because it's a possibility
that pain thresholds could be different due to very complex biological mechanisms. But we're only going to find that out
by talking about it. It shouldn't be an act of feminism to know how your body works. It shouldn't -- (Applause) It shouldn't be an act of feminism to ask for help when you're suffering. The era of menstrual taboos is over. (Cheers and applause) The only curse here is the ability to convince
half the population that the very biological machinery
that perpetuates the species, that gives everything that we have, is somehow dirty or toxic. And I'm not going to stand for it. (Applause) And the way we break that curse? It's knowledge. Thank you. (Cheers and applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How much blood does the uterus hold during menstruation?
Options: A. 12 ounces, B. 100 to 120 milliliters, C. 30 to 90 milliliters, D. 7 liters
Correct Option: C

It's because of patriarchal society's investment in oppressing women., C. It's because of the pain and discomfort associated with menstruation., D. It's because of the inconvenience it causes. Correct Option: None

To maximize the chance of a beneficial outcome by making embryos work for it., D. To reduce menstrual cramps. Correct Option: None

The pressure during the second stage of labor when pushing., D. The pressure of a headache. Correct Option: None

To increase knowledge and understanding of the female body., D. To encourage the use of hormonal contraception. Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years ago,
the Romans invented a material that allowed them to build 
much of their sprawling civilization. Pliny the Elder praised an imposing
sea wall made from the stuff as “impregnable to the waves
and every day stronger.” He was right: much of this construction
still stands, having survived millennia of battering 
by environmental forces that would topple modern buildings. Today, our roads, sidewalks, bridges, 
and skyscrapers are made of a similar, though 
less durable, material called concrete. There’s three tons of it for every person 
on Earth. And over the next 40 years, 
we’ll use enough of it to build the equivalent of New York City 
every single month. Concrete has shaped our skylines, but that's not the only way
it's changed our world. It’s also played a surprisingly large role
in rising global temperatures over the last century, a trend that has already 
changed the world, and threatens to even more drastically
in the coming decades. To be fair to concrete, basically
everything humanity does contributes to the greenhouse gas 
emissions that cause global warming. Most of those emissions come 
from industrial processes we often aren’t aware of, 
but touch every aspect of our lives. Look around your home. Refrigeration— 
along with other heating and cooling— makes up about 6% of total emissions. Agriculture, which produces our food,
accounts for 18%. Electricity is responsible for 27%. Walk outside, and the cars zipping past,
planes overhead, trains ferrying commuters to work— transportation, including shipping, contributes 16% 
of greenhouse gas emissions. Even before we use any of these things,
making them produces emissions— a lot of emissions. Making materials— concrete, steel, plastic, glass, 
aluminum and everything else— accounts for 31%
of greenhouse gas emissions. Concrete alone is responsible for 8% 
of all carbon emissions worldwide. And it’s much more difficult to reduce 
the emissions from concrete than from other building materials. The problem is cement, 
one of the four ingredients in concrete. It holds the other three ingredients—
gravel, sand, and water— together. Unfortunately, it's impossible to make
cement without generating carbon dioxide. The essential ingredient in cement
is calcium oxide, CaO. We get that calcium oxide from limestone, which is mostly made of calcium carbonate:
CaCO3. We extract CaO from CaCO3
by heating limestone. What’s left is CO2— carbon dioxide. So for every ton of cement we produce,
we release one ton of carbon dioxide. As tricky as this problem is, it means concrete could help
us change the world a third time: by eliminating greenhouse gas emissions
and stabilizing our climate. Right now, there’s no 100% clean concrete, but there are some great ideas
to help us get there. Cement manufacturing also produces
greenhouse gas emissions by burning fossil fuels 
to heat the limestone. Heating the limestone with clean 
electricity or alternative fuels instead would eliminate those emissions. For the carbon dioxide from
the limestone itself, our best bet is carbon capture: specifically, capturing the carbon
right where it’s produced, before it enters the atmosphere. Devices that do this already exist, but they aren’t widely used because
there’s no economic incentive. Transporting and then storing 
the captured carbon can be expensive. To solve these problems, one company has found a way to store
captured CO2 permanently in the concrete itself. Other innovators are tinkering with 
the fundamental chemistry of concrete. Some are investigating ways 
to reduce emissions by decreasing the cement in concrete. Still others have been working
to uncover and replicate the secrets of Roman concrete. They found that Pliny’s remark 
is literally true. The Romans used volcanic ash 
in their cement. When the ash interacted with seawater,
the seawater strengthened it— making their concrete stronger and more 
long-lasting than any we use today. By adding these findings to an arsenal 
of modern innovations, hopefully we can replicate their success— both by making long lasting structures, and ensuring our descendants can admire
them thousands of years from now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: There are ____ of concrete per person in the world
Options: A. 500 pounds, B. 3 tons, C. 10 tons, D. 875 pounds
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What ancient civilization is credited with inventing a material that allowed them to build their sprawling civilization? Options: A. Egyptians, B. Greeks, C. Romans, D. Mesopotamians Correct Option: None
Question 2: What percentage of greenhouse gas emissions is attributed to the production of materials such as concrete, steel, and plastic? Options: A. 16%, B. 27%, C. 31%, D. 40% Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the name of the Roman author who praised a sea wall made from Roman concrete as "impregnable to the waves and every day stronger"? Options: A. Julius Caesar, B. Pliny the Elder, C. Cicero, D. Virgil Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the estimated amount of concrete that will be used over the next 40 years? Options: A. Enough to build a city the size of New York City every year, B. Enough to build a city the size of New York City every month, C. Enough to build a city the size of New York City every decade, D. Enough to build a city the size of New York City every century Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the essential ingredient in cement that is responsible for generating carbon dioxide? Options: A. Silica, B. Calcium oxide, C. Aluminum oxide, D. Iron oxide Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the process by which calcium oxide is extracted from limestone? Options: A. Cooling, B. Heating, C. Mixing, D. Grinding Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the technology that can capture carbon dioxide emissions from cement production? Options: A. Carbon capture, B. Carbon sequestration, C. Carbon storage, D. Carbon reduction Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the main challenge in reducing greenhouse gas emissions from concrete production? Options: A. Lack of alternative materials, B. High cost of production, C. Difficulty in reducing cement content, D. Limited availability of limestone Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the unique component of Roman concrete that made it stronger and more long-lasting? Options: A. Volcanic ash, B. Seawater, C. Limestone, D. Sand Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the estimated percentage of global carbon emissions attributed to concrete production? Options: A. 5%, B. 8%, C. 10%, D. 15% Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the content and intent of the questions, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the amount of concrete per person in the world. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 4 talks about the estimated amount of concrete that will be used over the next 40 years, which is mentioned in the same context as the amount of concrete per person in the transcript.

However, a more relevant question would be one that directly asks about concrete production or consumption. Among the given options, Question 10 is the most relevant, as it asks about the estimated percentage of global carbon emissions attributed to concrete production. This question is related to the amount of concrete produced and used, which is indirectly related to the amount of concrete per person.

But since none of the questions directly match the ground truth MCQ, I will not provide an index.

the Romans invented a material that allowed them to build 
much of their sprawling civilization. Pliny the Elder praised an imposing

on Earth. And over the next 40 years, 
we’ll use enough of it to build the equivalent of New York City 
every single month. Concrete has shaped our skylines, but that's not the only way
it's changed our world. It’s also played a surprisingly large role
in rising global temperatures over the last century, a trend that has already 
changed the world, and threatens to even more drastically
in the coming decades. To be fair to concrete, basically

gravel, sand, and water— together. Unfortunately, it's impossible to make
cement without generating carbon dioxide. The essential ingredient in cement
is calcium oxide, CaO. We get that calcium oxide from limestone, which is mostly made of calcium carbonate:
CaCO3. We extract CaO from CaCO3
by heating limestone. What’s left is CO2— carbon dioxide. So for every ton of cement we produce,
we release one ton of carbon dioxide. As tricky as this problem is, it means concrete could help
us change the world a third time: by eliminating greenhouse gas emissions
and stabilizing our climate. Right now, there’s no 100% clean concrete, but there are some great ideas
to help us get there. Cement manufacturing also produces
greenhouse gas emissions by burning fossil fuels 
to heat the limestone. Heating the limestone with clean 
electricity or alternative fuels instead would eliminate those emissions. For the carbon dioxide from
the limestone itself, our best bet is carbon capture: specifically, capturing the carbon
right where it’s produced, before it enters the atmosphere. Devices that do this already exist, but they aren’t widely used because
there’s no economic incentive. Transporting and then storing 
the captured carbon can be expensive. To solve these problems, one company has found a way to store
captured CO2 permanently in the concrete itself. Other innovators are tinkering with 
the fundamental chemistry of concrete. Some are investigating ways 
to reduce emissions by decreasing the cement in concrete. Still others have been working
to uncover and replicate the secrets of Roman concrete. They found that Pliny’s remark 
is literally true. The Romans used volcanic ash 
in their cement. When the ash interacted with seawater,
the seawater strengthened it— making their concrete stronger and more 
long-lasting than any we use today. By adding these findings to an arsenal 
of modern innovations, hopefully we can replicate their success— both by making long lasting structures, and ensuring our descendants can admire
them thousands of years from now.

the Romans invented a material that allowed them to build 
much of their sprawling civilization. Pliny the Elder praised an imposing
sea wall made from the stuff as “impregnable to the waves
and every day stronger.” He was right: much of this construction

on Earth. And over the next 40 years, 
we’ll use enough of it to build the equivalent of New York City 
every single month. Concrete has shaped our skylines, but that's not the only way
it's changed our world. It’s also played a surprisingly large role
in rising global temperatures over the last century, a trend that has already 
changed the world, and threatens to even more drastically
in the coming decades. To be fair to concrete, basically
everything humanity does contributes to the greenhouse gas

from industrial processes we often aren’t aware of, 
but touch every aspect of our lives. Look around your home. Refrigeration—

aluminum and everything else— accounts for 31%

of all carbon emissions worldwide. And it’s much more difficult to reduce

one of the four ingredients in concrete. It holds the other three ingredients—
gravel, sand, and water— together. Unfortunately, it's impossible to make

is calcium oxide, CaO. We get that calcium oxide from limestone, which is mostly made of calcium carbonate:

by heating limestone. What’s left is CO2— carbon dioxide. So for every ton of cement we produce,
we release one ton of carbon dioxide. As tricky as this problem is, it means concrete could help
us change the world a third time: by eliminating greenhouse gas emissions

them thousands of years from now.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years ago,
the Romans invented a material that allowed them to build 
much of their sprawling civilization. Pliny the Elder praised an imposing
sea wall made from the stuff as “impregnable to the waves
and every day stronger.” He was right: much of this construction
still stands, having survived millennia of battering 
by environmental forces that would topple modern buildings. Today, our roads, sidewalks, bridges, 
and skyscrapers are made of a similar, though 
less durable, material called concrete. There’s three tons of it for every person 
on Earth. And over the next 40 years, 
we’ll use enough of it to build the equivalent of New York City 
every single month. Concrete has shaped our skylines, but that's not the only way
it's changed our world. It’s also played a surprisingly large role
in rising global temperatures over the last century, a trend that has already 
changed the world, and threatens to even more drastically
in the coming decades. To be fair to concrete, basically
everything humanity does contributes to the greenhouse gas 
emissions that cause global warming. Most of those emissions come 
from industrial processes we often aren’t aware of, 
but touch every aspect of our lives. Look around your home. Refrigeration— 
along with other heating and cooling— makes up about 6% of total emissions. Agriculture, which produces our food,
accounts for 18%. Electricity is responsible for 27%. Walk outside, and the cars zipping past,
planes overhead, trains ferrying commuters to work— transportation, including shipping, contributes 16% 
of greenhouse gas emissions. Even before we use any of these things,
making them produces emissions— a lot of emissions. Making materials— concrete, steel, plastic, glass, 
aluminum and everything else— accounts for 31%
of greenhouse gas emissions. Concrete alone is responsible for 8% 
of all carbon emissions worldwide. And it’s much more difficult to reduce 
the emissions from concrete than from other building materials. The problem is cement, 
one of the four ingredients in concrete. It holds the other three ingredients—
gravel, sand, and water— together. Unfortunately, it's impossible to make
cement without generating carbon dioxide. The essential ingredient in cement
is calcium oxide, CaO. We get that calcium oxide from limestone, which is mostly made of calcium carbonate:
CaCO3. We extract CaO from CaCO3
by heating limestone. What’s left is CO2— carbon dioxide. So for every ton of cement we produce,
we release one ton of carbon dioxide. As tricky as this problem is, it means concrete could help
us change the world a third time: by eliminating greenhouse gas emissions
and stabilizing our climate. Right now, there’s no 100% clean concrete, but there are some great ideas
to help us get there. Cement manufacturing also produces
greenhouse gas emissions by burning fossil fuels 
to heat the limestone. Heating the limestone with clean 
electricity or alternative fuels instead would eliminate those emissions. For the carbon dioxide from
the limestone itself, our best bet is carbon capture: specifically, capturing the carbon
right where it’s produced, before it enters the atmosphere. Devices that do this already exist, but they aren’t widely used because
there’s no economic incentive. Transporting and then storing 
the captured carbon can be expensive. To solve these problems, one company has found a way to store
captured CO2 permanently in the concrete itself. Other innovators are tinkering with 
the fundamental chemistry of concrete. Some are investigating ways 
to reduce emissions by decreasing the cement in concrete. Still others have been working
to uncover and replicate the secrets of Roman concrete. They found that Pliny’s remark 
is literally true. The Romans used volcanic ash 
in their cement. When the ash interacted with seawater,
the seawater strengthened it— making their concrete stronger and more 
long-lasting than any we use today. By adding these findings to an arsenal 
of modern innovations, hopefully we can replicate their success— both by making long lasting structures, and ensuring our descendants can admire
them thousands of years from now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following compounds is essential in making cement:
Options: A. Carbon Dioxide, B. Calcium Oxide, C. Ozone, D. Hydrogen oxide
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What ancient civilization is credited with inventing a material that allowed them to build their sprawling civilization? Options: A. Egyptians, B. Greeks, C. Romans, D. Mesopotamians Correct Option: None
Question 2: What percentage of greenhouse gas emissions is attributed to the production of materials such as concrete, steel, and plastic? Options: A. 16%, B. 27%, C. 31%, D. 40% Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the name of the Roman author who praised a sea wall made from Roman concrete as "impregnable to the waves and every day stronger"? Options: A. Julius Caesar, B. Pliny the Elder, C. Cicero, D. Virgil Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the estimated amount of concrete that will be used over the next 40 years? Options: A. Enough to build a city the size of New York City every year, B. Enough to build a city the size of New York City every month, C. Enough to build a city the size of New York City every decade, D. Enough to build a city the size of New York City every century Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the essential ingredient in cement that is responsible for generating carbon dioxide? Options: A. Silica, B. Calcium oxide, C. Aluminum oxide, D. Iron oxide Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the process by which calcium oxide is extracted from limestone? Options: A. Cooling, B. Heating, C. Mixing, D. Grinding Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the technology that can capture carbon dioxide emissions from cement production? Options: A. Carbon capture, B. Carbon sequestration, C. Carbon storage, D. Carbon reduction Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the main challenge in reducing greenhouse gas emissions from concrete production? Options: A. Lack of alternative materials, B. High cost of production, C. Difficulty in reducing cement content, D. Limited availability of limestone Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the unique component of Roman concrete that made it stronger and more long-lasting? Options: A. Volcanic ash, B. Seawater, C. Limestone, D. Sand Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the estimated percentage of global carbon emissions attributed to concrete production? Options: A. 5%, B. 8%, C. 10%, D. 15% Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5: What is the essential ingredient in cement that is responsible for generating carbon dioxide? Options: A. Silica, B. Calcium oxide, C. Aluminum oxide, D. Iron oxide.

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the essential ingredient in cement, and both have calcium oxide as the correct answer.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years ago,
the Romans invented a material that allowed them to build 
much of their sprawling civilization. Pliny the Elder praised an imposing
sea wall made from the stuff as “impregnable to the waves
and every day stronger.” He was right: much of this construction
still stands, having survived millennia of battering 
by environmental forces that would topple modern buildings. Today, our roads, sidewalks, bridges, 
and skyscrapers are made of a similar, though 
less durable, material called concrete. There’s three tons of it for every person 
on Earth. And over the next 40 years, 
we’ll use enough of it to build the equivalent of New York City 
every single month. Concrete has shaped our skylines, but that's not the only way
it's changed our world. It’s also played a surprisingly large role
in rising global temperatures over the last century, a trend that has already 
changed the world, and threatens to even more drastically
in the coming decades. To be fair to concrete, basically
everything humanity does contributes to the greenhouse gas 
emissions that cause global warming. Most of those emissions come 
from industrial processes we often aren’t aware of, 
but touch every aspect of our lives. Look around your home. Refrigeration— 
along with other heating and cooling— makes up about 6% of total emissions. Agriculture, which produces our food,
accounts for 18%. Electricity is responsible for 27%. Walk outside, and the cars zipping past,
planes overhead, trains ferrying commuters to work— transportation, including shipping, contributes 16% 
of greenhouse gas emissions. Even before we use any of these things,
making them produces emissions— a lot of emissions. Making materials— concrete, steel, plastic, glass, 
aluminum and everything else— accounts for 31%
of greenhouse gas emissions. Concrete alone is responsible for 8% 
of all carbon emissions worldwide. And it’s much more difficult to reduce 
the emissions from concrete than from other building materials. The problem is cement, 
one of the four ingredients in concrete. It holds the other three ingredients—
gravel, sand, and water— together. Unfortunately, it's impossible to make
cement without generating carbon dioxide. The essential ingredient in cement
is calcium oxide, CaO. We get that calcium oxide from limestone, which is mostly made of calcium carbonate:
CaCO3. We extract CaO from CaCO3
by heating limestone. What’s left is CO2— carbon dioxide. So for every ton of cement we produce,
we release one ton of carbon dioxide. As tricky as this problem is, it means concrete could help
us change the world a third time: by eliminating greenhouse gas emissions
and stabilizing our climate. Right now, there’s no 100% clean concrete, but there are some great ideas
to help us get there. Cement manufacturing also produces
greenhouse gas emissions by burning fossil fuels 
to heat the limestone. Heating the limestone with clean 
electricity or alternative fuels instead would eliminate those emissions. For the carbon dioxide from
the limestone itself, our best bet is carbon capture: specifically, capturing the carbon
right where it’s produced, before it enters the atmosphere. Devices that do this already exist, but they aren’t widely used because
there’s no economic incentive. Transporting and then storing 
the captured carbon can be expensive. To solve these problems, one company has found a way to store
captured CO2 permanently in the concrete itself. Other innovators are tinkering with 
the fundamental chemistry of concrete. Some are investigating ways 
to reduce emissions by decreasing the cement in concrete. Still others have been working
to uncover and replicate the secrets of Roman concrete. They found that Pliny’s remark 
is literally true. The Romans used volcanic ash 
in their cement. When the ash interacted with seawater,
the seawater strengthened it— making their concrete stronger and more 
long-lasting than any we use today. By adding these findings to an arsenal 
of modern innovations, hopefully we can replicate their success— both by making long lasting structures, and ensuring our descendants can admire
them thousands of years from now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or False: the ancient romans used volcanic ash and seawater to make concrete
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As of 2020, the world’s biggest 
lithium-ion battery is hooked up to the Southern California 
power grid and can provide 250 million watts 
of power, or enough to power about 250,000 homes. But it’s actually not the biggest battery
in the world: these lakes are. Wait— how can a pair of lakes 
be a battery? To answer that question, 
it helps to define a battery: it’s simply something that stores energy
and releases it on demand. The lithium-ion batteries that power 
our phones, laptops, and cars are just one type. They store energy in lithium ions. To release the energy, the ions 
are separated from their electrons, then rejoined at the other end 
of the battery as a new molecule with lower energy. How do the two lakes 
store and release energy? First, one is 300 meters higher 
than the other. Electricity powers pumps that move
billions of liters of water from the lower lake to the higher one. This stores the energy by giving the water
extra gravitational potential energy. Then, when there’s high demand
for electricity, valves open, releasing the stored energy 
by letting water flow downhill to power 6 giant turbines that can 
generate 3 billion watts of power for 10 hours. We’re going to need more and more 
giant batteries. That’s because right now, generating
enough electricity to power the world produces an unsustainable amount 
of greenhouse gas: 14 billion tons per year. We’ll need to get that number 
down to net-zero. But many clean energy sources 
can’t produce electricity 24/7. So to make the switch, we need a way to
store the electricity until it's needed. That means we need grid-scale batteries: batteries big enough 
to power multiple cities. Unfortunately, neither of the giant
batteries we’ve talked about so far can solve this problem. The two lakes setup requires specific
geography, takes up a lot of land, and has high upfront costs to build. The giant lithium-ion battery
in California, meanwhile, can power about 250,000 homes, yes,
but only for an hour. Lithium-ion batteries are great for things
that don’t use a lot of power. But to store a lot of energy, 
they have to be huge and heavy. That’s why electric planes aren’t a thing: the best electric plane 
can only carry two people for about 1,000 kilometers on one charge, or its batteries would be too heavy 
to fly. A typical commercial jet can carry 
300 people over 14,000 km before refueling. Lithium-ion batteries also require 
certain heavy metals to make. These resources are limited, and mining
them often causes environmental damage. Inventors all over the world are rising 
to the challenge of making batteries that can meet 
our needs— many of them even weirder 
than the two lakes. One company is building 
a skyscraper battery. When the sun is shining, 
a crane powered by solar energy piles blocks on top of each other 
in a tower. At night, the cranes let gravity
pull the blocks down and use the resulting power 
to spin generators. Though there have been
some early setbacks, another promising approach involves
heating up salts until they melt. The molten salt can be stored until 
there’s a high demand for electricity, then used to boil water. The steam can power turbines
that generate electricity. Another idea: bio-batteries made 
from paper, powered by bacteria, and activated by spit. Bacteria release energy in the form 
of electrons when they metabolize glucose, and at least one species of bacteria can
transfer those electrons outside its cells,
completing a circuit. While these batteries won’t power
a city, or even a house, they don't have the waste and cost
concerns of traditional batteries. From vast mountain lakes 
to microscopic bacteria, from seawater batteries
that bypass the need for heavy metals to nuclear batteries
that power deep space missions, we're constantly rethinking
what a battery can be. The next unlikely battery could
be hiding in plain sight— just waiting to be discovered 
and help us achieve a sustainable future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 1. The world’s most powerful lithium-ion battery can generate ______ watts of power
Options: A. 250 Million , B. 150 Billion, C. 150 Million, D. 1 Billion, E. 3 Trillion
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the world's biggest lithium-ion battery capable of providing in terms of power? Options: A. 100 million watts of power, B. 250 million watts of power, C. 500 million watts of power, D. 1 billion watts of power Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary function of a battery? Options: A. To generate electricity, B. To store energy and release it on demand, C. To power electronic devices, D. To reduce greenhouse gas emissions Correct Option: None
Question 3: How do the two lakes store energy? Options: A. By using lithium ions, B. By giving water extra gravitational potential energy, C. By heating up salts, D. By using bacteria to release energy Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the purpose of the valves in the two lakes setup? Options: A. To pump water from the lower lake to the higher lake, B. To release the stored energy by letting water flow downhill, C. To generate electricity, D. To power the turbines Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why do we need grid-scale batteries? Options: A. To power electronic devices, B. To reduce greenhouse gas emissions, C. To store electricity until it's needed, D. To generate electricity 24/7 Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is a limitation of lithium-ion batteries? Options: A. They are too expensive, B. They require specific geography, C. They have to be huge and heavy to store a lot of energy, D. They are not environmentally friendly Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is a potential environmental concern of lithium-ion batteries? Options: A. They produce greenhouse gas emissions, B. They require certain heavy metals to make, C. They are not recyclable, D. They are not biodegradable Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the idea behind the skyscraper battery? Options: A. To use solar energy to power a crane that piles blocks on top of each other, B. To use wind energy to power a turbine that generates electricity, C. To use hydro energy to power a generator that produces electricity, D. To use geothermal energy to power a heat pump that provides heating and cooling Correct Option: None
Question 9: How do bio-batteries made from paper work? Options: A. They use solar energy to generate electricity, B. They use bacteria to release energy in the form of electrons, C. They use molten salt to boil water and generate steam, D. They use nuclear reactions to generate electricity Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why are inventors trying to develop new types of batteries? Options: A. To increase the efficiency of electronic devices, B. To reduce the cost of electricity, C. To achieve a sustainable future by reducing greenhouse gas emissions, D. To increase the power of electric vehicles Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1: "What is the world's biggest lithium-ion battery capable of providing in terms of power?"

This question has a similar intent and content to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the power generation capacity of the world's most powerful lithium-ion battery. The options in the generated MCQ also include the correct answer (250 million watts of power), although it is not explicitly marked as the correct option.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 2

and help us achieve a sustainable future.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As of 2020, the world’s biggest 
lithium-ion battery is hooked up to the Southern California 
power grid and can provide 250 million watts 
of power, or enough to power about 250,000 homes. But it’s actually not the biggest battery
in the world: these lakes are. Wait— how can a pair of lakes 
be a battery? To answer that question, 
it helps to define a battery: it’s simply something that stores energy
and releases it on demand. The lithium-ion batteries that power 
our phones, laptops, and cars are just one type. They store energy in lithium ions. To release the energy, the ions 
are separated from their electrons, then rejoined at the other end 
of the battery as a new molecule with lower energy. How do the two lakes 
store and release energy? First, one is 300 meters higher 
than the other. Electricity powers pumps that move

extra gravitational potential energy. Then, when there’s high demand

giant batteries. That’s because right now, generating
enough electricity to power the world produces an unsustainable amount

than the two lakes. One company is building 
a skyscraper battery. When the sun is shining, 
a crane powered by solar energy piles blocks on top of each other 
in a tower. At night, the cranes let gravity
pull the blocks down and use the resulting power 
to spin generators. Though there have been
some early setbacks, another promising approach involves
heating up salts until they melt. The molten salt can be stored until 
there’s a high demand for electricity, then used to boil water. The steam can power turbines
that generate electricity. Another idea: bio-batteries made 
from paper, powered by bacteria, and activated by spit. Bacteria release energy in the form 
of electrons when they metabolize glucose, and at least one species of bacteria can
transfer those electrons outside its cells,
completing a circuit. While these batteries won’t power
a city, or even a house, they don't have the waste and cost
concerns of traditional batteries. From vast mountain lakes 
to microscopic bacteria, from seawater batteries
that bypass the need for heavy metals to nuclear batteries
that power deep space missions, we're constantly rethinking
what a battery can be. The next unlikely battery could
be hiding in plain sight— just waiting to be discovered 
and help us achieve a sustainable future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What’s the definition of a battery?
Options: A. Electrical grid that delivers electricity, B. The capacity to exert power, C. Something that stores and releases energy on demand
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the world's biggest lithium-ion battery capable of providing in terms of power? Options: A. 100 million watts of power, B. 250 million watts of power, C. 500 million watts of power, D. 1 billion watts of power Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary function of a battery? Options: A. To generate electricity, B. To store energy and release it on demand, C. To power electronic devices, D. To reduce greenhouse gas emissions Correct Option: None
Question 3: How do the two lakes store energy? Options: A. By using lithium ions, B. By giving water extra gravitational potential energy, C. By heating up salts, D. By using bacteria to release energy Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the purpose of the valves in the two lakes setup? Options: A. To pump water from the lower lake to the higher lake, B. To release the stored energy by letting water flow downhill, C. To generate electricity, D. To power the turbines Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why do we need grid-scale batteries? Options: A. To power electronic devices, B. To reduce greenhouse gas emissions, C. To store electricity until it's needed, D. To generate electricity 24/7 Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is a limitation of lithium-ion batteries? Options: A. They are too expensive, B. They require specific geography, C. They have to be huge and heavy to store a lot of energy, D. They are not environmentally friendly Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is a potential environmental concern of lithium-ion batteries? Options: A. They produce greenhouse gas emissions, B. They require certain heavy metals to make, C. They are not recyclable, D. They are not biodegradable Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the idea behind the skyscraper battery? Options: A. To use solar energy to power a crane that piles blocks on top of each other, B. To use wind energy to power a turbine that generates electricity, C. To use hydro energy to power a generator that produces electricity, D. To use geothermal energy to power a heat pump that provides heating and cooling Correct Option: None
Question 9: How do bio-batteries made from paper work? Options: A. They use solar energy to generate electricity, B. They use bacteria to release energy in the form of electrons, C. They use molten salt to boil water and generate steam, D. They use nuclear reactions to generate electricity Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why are inventors trying to develop new types of batteries? Options: A. To increase the efficiency of electronic devices, B. To reduce the cost of electricity, C. To achieve a sustainable future by reducing greenhouse gas emissions, D. To increase the power of electric vehicles Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: What is the primary function of a battery? Options: A. To generate electricity, B. To store energy and release it on demand, C. To power electronic devices, D. To reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent and content, as both questions aim to define the fundamental purpose of a battery. The correct option in the generated MCQ, "To store energy and release it on demand," is identical to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "Something that stores and releases energy on demand."

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As of 2020, the world’s biggest 
lithium-ion battery is hooked up to the Southern California 
power grid and can provide 250 million watts 
of power, or enough to power about 250,000 homes. But it’s actually not the biggest battery
in the world: these lakes are. Wait— how can a pair of lakes 
be a battery? To answer that question, 
it helps to define a battery: it’s simply something that stores energy
and releases it on demand. The lithium-ion batteries that power 
our phones, laptops, and cars are just one type. They store energy in lithium ions. To release the energy, the ions 
are separated from their electrons, then rejoined at the other end 
of the battery as a new molecule with lower energy. How do the two lakes 
store and release energy? First, one is 300 meters higher 
than the other. Electricity powers pumps that move
billions of liters of water from the lower lake to the higher one. This stores the energy by giving the water
extra gravitational potential energy. Then, when there’s high demand
for electricity, valves open, releasing the stored energy 
by letting water flow downhill to power 6 giant turbines that can 
generate 3 billion watts of power for 10 hours. We’re going to need more and more 
giant batteries. That’s because right now, generating
enough electricity to power the world produces an unsustainable amount 
of greenhouse gas: 14 billion tons per year. We’ll need to get that number 
down to net-zero. But many clean energy sources 
can’t produce electricity 24/7. So to make the switch, we need a way to
store the electricity until it's needed. That means we need grid-scale batteries: batteries big enough 
to power multiple cities. Unfortunately, neither of the giant
batteries we’ve talked about so far can solve this problem. The two lakes setup requires specific
geography, takes up a lot of land, and has high upfront costs to build. The giant lithium-ion battery
in California, meanwhile, can power about 250,000 homes, yes,
but only for an hour. Lithium-ion batteries are great for things
that don’t use a lot of power. But to store a lot of energy, 
they have to be huge and heavy. That’s why electric planes aren’t a thing: the best electric plane 
can only carry two people for about 1,000 kilometers on one charge, or its batteries would be too heavy 
to fly. A typical commercial jet can carry 
300 people over 14,000 km before refueling. Lithium-ion batteries also require 
certain heavy metals to make. These resources are limited, and mining
them often causes environmental damage. Inventors all over the world are rising 
to the challenge of making batteries that can meet 
our needs— many of them even weirder 
than the two lakes. One company is building 
a skyscraper battery. When the sun is shining, 
a crane powered by solar energy piles blocks on top of each other 
in a tower. At night, the cranes let gravity
pull the blocks down and use the resulting power 
to spin generators. Though there have been
some early setbacks, another promising approach involves
heating up salts until they melt. The molten salt can be stored until 
there’s a high demand for electricity, then used to boil water. The steam can power turbines
that generate electricity. Another idea: bio-batteries made 
from paper, powered by bacteria, and activated by spit. Bacteria release energy in the form 
of electrons when they metabolize glucose, and at least one species of bacteria can
transfer those electrons outside its cells,
completing a circuit. While these batteries won’t power
a city, or even a house, they don't have the waste and cost
concerns of traditional batteries. From vast mountain lakes 
to microscopic bacteria, from seawater batteries
that bypass the need for heavy metals to nuclear batteries
that power deep space missions, we're constantly rethinking
what a battery can be. The next unlikely battery could
be hiding in plain sight— just waiting to be discovered 
and help us achieve a sustainable future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why aren’t lithium-ion batteries good for storing lots of energy?
Options: A. They expire after frequent use, B. They have to be huge and heavy, C. They don’t release all their stored energy, D. They need to be recharged frequently
Correct Option: B

Question 7: What is a potential environmental concern of lithium-ion batteries? Options: A. They produce greenhouse gas emissions, B. They require certain heavy metals to make, C. They are not recyclable, D. They are not biodegradable Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the idea behind the skyscraper battery? Options: A. To use solar energy to power a crane that piles blocks on top of each other, B. To use wind energy to power a turbine that generates electricity, C. To use hydro energy to power a generator that produces electricity, D. To use geothermal energy to power a heat pump that provides heating and cooling Correct Option: None

They use molten salt to boil water and generate steam, D. They use nuclear reactions to generate electricity Correct Option: None

To achieve a sustainable future by reducing greenhouse gas emissions, D. To increase the power of electric vehicles Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 5

of power, or enough to power about 250,000 homes. But it’s actually not the biggest battery
in the world: these lakes are. Wait— how can a pair of lakes 
be a battery? To answer that question,

and releases it on demand. The lithium-ion batteries that power

than the two lakes. One company is building

a crane powered by solar energy piles blocks on top of each other 
in a tower. At night, the cranes let gravity
pull the blocks down and use the resulting power 
to spin generators. Though there have been
some early setbacks, another promising approach involves
heating up salts until they melt. The molten salt can be stored until

completing a circuit. While these batteries won’t power

concerns of traditional batteries. From vast mountain lakes 
to microscopic bacteria, from seawater batteries
that bypass the need for heavy metals to nuclear batteries
that power deep space missions, we're constantly rethinking
what a battery can be. The next unlikely battery could
be hiding in plain sight— just waiting to be discovered 
and help us achieve a sustainable future.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Two frogs are minding their own business
in the swamp when WHAM— they’re kidnapped. They come to in a kitchen, 
captives of a menacing chef. He boils up a pot of water 
and lobs one of the frogs in. But it’s having none of this. The second its toes hit the scalding water
it jumps right out the window. The chef refills the pot, but this time 
he doesn’t turn on the heat. He plops the second frog in,
and this frog’s okay with that. The chef turns the heat on, very low, 
and the temperature of water slowly rises. So slowly that the frog doesn’t notice. In fact, it basks in the balmy water. Only when the surface begins to bubble
does the frog realize: it’s toast. What’s funny about this parable is that
it’s not scientifically true... for frogs. In reality, a frog will detect slowly
heating water and leap to safety. Humans, on the other hand,
are a different story. We’re perfectly happy to sit in the pot 
and slowly turn up the heat, all the while insisting it isn’t our hand
on the dial, arguing about whether we can 
trust thermometers, and questioning— 
even if they’re right, does it matter? It does. Since 1850, global average temperatures 
have risen by 1 degree Celsius. That may not sound like a lot, but it is. Why? 1 degree is an average. Many places have already gotten
much warmer than that. Some places in the Arctic 
have already warmed 4 degrees. If global average temperatures 
increase 1 more degree, the coldest nights in the Arctic
might get 10 degrees warmer. The warmest days in Mumbai 
might get 5 degrees hotter. So how did we get here? Almost everything that makes modern life
possible relies on fossil fuels: coal, oil, and gas full of carbon 
from ancient organic matter. When we burn fossil fuels, we release carbon dioxide 
that builds up in our atmosphere, where it remains for hundreds 
or even thousands of years, letting heat in, but not out. The heat comes from sunlight, which passes
through the atmosphere to Earth, where it gets absorbed 
and warms everything up. Warm objects emit infrared radiation,
which should pass back out into space, because most atmospheric gases 
don’t absorb it. But greenhouse gases—
carbon dioxide and methane— do absorb infrared wavelengths. So when we add more of those gases 
to the atmosphere, less heat makes it back out to space, 
and our planet warms up. If we keep emitting greenhouse gases 
at our current pace, scientists predict temperatures
will rise 4 degrees from their pre-industrial levels by 2100. They’ve identified 1.5 degrees of warming— global averages half a degree warmer 
than today’s— as a threshold beyond which 
the negative impacts of climate change will become increasingly severe. To keep from crossing that threshold, we need to get our greenhouse gas 
emissions down to zero as fast as possible. Or rather, we have to get emissions
down to what's called net zero, meaning we may still be putting some
greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, but we take out as much as we put in. This doesn’t mean we can just keep 
emitting and sequester all that carbon— we couldn’t keep up with our emissions 
through natural methods, and technological solutions would
be prohibitively expensive and require huge amounts
of permanent storage. Instead, while we switch 
from coal, oil, and natural gas to clean energy and fuels, 
which will take time, we can mitigate the damage by removing
carbon from the atmosphere. Jumping out of the proverbial pot 
isn’t an option, but we can do something the frogs can’t: reach over, and turn down the heat.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Since 1850, global temperatures have increased by an average of:
Options: A. 1 Degree Fahrenheit, B. 3 Degrees Celsius, C. 1 Degree Celsius, D. 10 Degree Fahrenheit
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What happens to the first frog when it is thrown into the boiling water? Options: A. It gets cooked immediately, B. It jumps out of the window, C. It gets rescued by the chef, D. It stays in the water Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the result of slowly heating the water with the second frog in it? Options: A. The frog jumps out immediately, B. The frog gets cooked without realizing it, C. The frog realizes the heat and jumps out, D. The frog starts to boil the water itself Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the scientific truth about frogs in slowly heating water? Options: A. They get cooked without realizing it, B. They detect the heat and leap to safety, C. They start to boil the water themselves, D. They stay in the water forever Correct Option: None
Question 4: What has happened to global average temperatures since 1850? Options: A. They have decreased by 1 degree Celsius, B. They have increased by 1 degree Celsius, C. They have stayed the same, D. They have fluctuated randomly Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the predicted temperature rise by 2100 if greenhouse gas emissions continue at the current pace? Options: A. 1 degree Celsius, B. 2 degrees Celsius, C. 3 degrees Celsius, D. 4 degrees Celsius Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the identified threshold beyond which the negative impacts of climate change will become increasingly severe? Options: A. 1 degree Celsius of warming, B. 1.5 degrees Celsius of warming, C. 2 degrees Celsius of warming, D. 3 degrees Celsius of warming Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the goal to prevent crossing the threshold of severe climate change impacts? Options: A. Reduce greenhouse gas emissions by half, B. Get greenhouse gas emissions down to zero as fast as possible, C. Increase greenhouse gas emissions to speed up global warming, D. Keep greenhouse gas emissions at the current level Correct Option: None
Question 8: What does "net zero" emissions mean? Options: A. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions to zero immediately, B. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions by half, C. Emitting and removing an equal amount of greenhouse gases, D. Increasing greenhouse gas emissions to speed up global warming Correct Option: None
Question 9: Why can't we just keep emitting greenhouse gases and sequester all the carbon? Options: A. It's too expensive, B. It's too time-consuming, C. Natural methods can't keep up with emissions, and technological solutions are prohibitively expensive, D. It's not necessary to reduce emissions Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the proposed solution to mitigate the damage of climate change while transitioning to clean energy? Options: A. Removing carbon from the atmosphere, B. Increasing greenhouse gas emissions, C. Reducing energy consumption, D. Implementing a global carbon tax Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

Here's why:

- Question intent: Both the ground truth MCQ and Question 4 ask about the change in global average temperatures since 1850.
- Options: Both questions have options that include a specific temperature change (1 degree Celsius) and other distractors.
- Content: Both questions focus on the same topic, which is the change in global average temperatures since 1850.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 4.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Two frogs are minding their own business
in the swamp when WHAM— they’re kidnapped. They come to in a kitchen, 
captives of a menacing chef. He boils up a pot of water 
and lobs one of the frogs in. But it’s having none of this. The second its toes hit the scalding water
it jumps right out the window. The chef refills the pot, but this time 
he doesn’t turn on the heat. He plops the second frog in,
and this frog’s okay with that. The chef turns the heat on, very low, 
and the temperature of water slowly rises. So slowly that the frog doesn’t notice. In fact, it basks in the balmy water. Only when the surface begins to bubble
